t: Numbers 23
Balaam’s Oracles
Then*p Balaam said to Balak, “Build me seven altars here and prepare seven bulls and seven rams for me.”
So Balak did as Balaam directed, and they offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
Balaam said to Balak, “Stay here by your burnt offering while I am gone. Maybe the Lord*s will meet with me. I will tell you whatever he reveals to me.” So he went to a barren hill.
God*p met with him and Balaam said to him, “I have arranged seven altars and offered a bull and a ram on each altar.”
Then the Lord*s put a message in Balaam’s mouth and said, “Return to Balak and say what I tell you.”
So*p he returned to Balak, who was standing there by his burnt offering with all the officials of Moab.
Balaam’s First Oracle
Balaam*p proclaimed his poem: Balak*pn brought me from Aram; the*ln king of Moab, from the eastern mountains: “Come,*ln put a curse on Jacob for me; come,*ln denounce Israel!”
How*ln can I curse someone God has not cursed? How*ln can I denounce someone the Lord*s has not denounced?
I*ln see them from the top of rocky cliffs, and*ln I watch them from the hills. There*ln is a people living alone; it*ln does not consider itself among the nations.
Who*ln has counted the dust of Jacob or*ln numbered even one-fourth of Israel? Let*ln me die the death of the upright; let*ln the end of my life be like theirs.
“What*p have you done to me?” Balak asked Balaam. “I brought you to curse my enemies, but look, you have only blessed them!”
He*p answered, “Shouldn’t I say exactly what the Lord*s puts in my mouth?”
Balaam’s Second Oracle

Then*p Balak said to him, “Please come with me to another place where you can see them. You will only see the outskirts of their camp; you won’t see all of them. From there, put a curse on them for me.”
So Balak took him to Lookout Field on top of Pisgah, built seven altars, and offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
Balaam*p said to Balak, “Stay here by your burnt offering while I seek the Lord*s over there.”
The*p Lord*s met with Balaam and put a message in his mouth. Then he said, “Return to Balak and say what I tell you.”
So*p he returned to Balak, who was standing there by his burnt offering with the officials of Moab. Balak asked him, “What did the Lord*s say?”
Balaam*p proclaimed his poem: Balak,*pn get up and listen; son*ln of Zippor, pay attention to what I say!
God*ln is not a man, that he might lie, or*ln a son of man, that he might change his mind. Does*ln he speak and not act, or*ln promise and not fulfill?
I*ln have indeed received a command to bless; since*ln he has blessed, I cannot change it.
He*ln considers no disaster for Jacob; he*ln sees no trouble for Israel. The*ln Lord*s their God is with them, and*ln there is rejoicing over the King among them.
God*ln brought them out of Egypt; he*ln is like the horns of a wild ox for them.
There*ln is no magic curse against Jacob and*ln no divination against Israel. It*ln will now be said about Jacob and Israel, “What*ln great things God has done!”
A*ln people rise up like a lioness; they*ln rouse themselves like a lion. They*ln will not lie down until they devour the prey and*ln drink the blood of the slain.
Then*p Balak told Balaam, “Don’t curse them and don’t bless them!”
But*p Balaam answered him, “Didn’t I tell you: Whatever the Lord*s says, I must do?”
Balaam’s Third Oracle
Again*p Balak said to Balaam, “Please come. I will take you to another place. Maybe it will be agreeable to God that you can put a curse on them for me there.”
So Balak took Balaam to the top of Peor, which overlooks the wasteland.
Balaam*p told Balak, “Build me seven altars here and prepare seven bulls and seven rams for me.”
So Balak did as Balaam said and offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
